awd_titl_txt: Investigating how the cellular ER stress machinery regulates plant virus infection
awd_abstract_narration:
This research uses cultivated potato, which is the world's third largest food crop after wheat and rice.  While most crops grow from true seeds, potatoes are vegetatively propagated and multiplied for several years in the field.  Without proper management, disease incidence in potato can rise to devastating levels within a few years. PVX and PVY are significant viruses that gravely impact potato yield and marketability, and economically impact producers.  The global spread of necrotic PVY strains has created new challenges for producers. There is an urgent need to advance the knowledge of genes in potato responding to virus disease. The overarching, long- term goal is to improve potato resistance to PVX and PVY infection.  This research will uncover the mechanisms of how plants can respond to virus stress and adapt to challenging environments.  This research will investigate a key set of stress response genes that protect plants against drought and virus infection.  This research will also explore how a set of proteins known as BiPs suppress disease and determine how these can be used to provide protection against virus infection.  We will use this information to improve potato production strategies and effective breeding practices. 

The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a central hub for responses to adverse environmental challenges in plants such as virus infection, heat, chemical, osmotic, and salt stress. The physiological consequences of prolonged low-level ER stress include constrained plant development and productivity, whereas chronic stress can result in death and crop losses. Three well known monitoring/sensing pathway use the transcription factors bZIP60, bZIP28 and/or bZIP17 to activate cellular adaptive responses. They coordinate the transcription of molecular chaperones, including the ER lumen binding protein (BiP). It is well known that Arabidopsis plants overexpressing certain BiP isoforms display greater tolerance to virus infections and heat and osmotic stresses.  The central hypothesis motivating the project is that bZIP60, bZIP28, and bZIP17 differentially up-regulate expression of BiP isoforms that ameliorates ER stress and cell death regulation in solanaceous plants, such as potato and tobacco. The research team will test a model in which ER stress sensors and BiP isoforms are engaged in N. benthamiana and potato to provide cellular protection against virus infection.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Potato is the world’s third largest food crop but yields are badly damaged by potyvirus and potexvirus infections. There is an urgent need in potato to advance the knowledge of genes responding to virus disease. This research began when the potato genome was poorly annotated and there was a significant knowledge gap of how the cellular endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress machinery recognizes and responds to virus infection. Three bZIP transcription factors, namely bZIP60, bZIP28, and bZIP17 are also known in Arabidopsis to regulate ER stress but their orthologues in potato and many other plants are not known.  These transcription factors regulate the expression of numerous genes that protect plants against environmental damange.  For example, it is well known that Arabidopsis plants overexpressing certain BiP isoforms, which reside in the ER, display greater tolerance to virus infection, heat, and drought stress. The potato BiP isoforms that respond specifically to virus infection were not known when the project began.  In this context, our central hypothesis motivating the proposed research is that bZIP60, bZIP28, and bZIP17 differentially upregulate expression of BiP isoforms that ameliorates ER stress and cell death in potato plants. This proposed research tests a model in which ER stress sensors and BiP isoforms are engaged to provide cellular protection against virus infection.  At the conclusion of this project, we achieved a well-establishing a comparative genetic system of Arabidopsis, yeast, and potato for the discovery of novel host factors regulating of virus-plant interactions; (2) identifying critical ER stress-associated gene orthologues in potato that are important for stress resistance; (3)  functionally annotating genes that are critical for  improvement of the agriculturally important crop, potato; and (4) generating transgenic potato lines that expresses informed genetic modifications in BiP that are expected to improve its tolerance and resistance to virus.

Broader Impacts:

This research produced outputs to advance the current research in ER stress responses to pathogen infection, as well as regionally in STEM education and outreach at Texas A&M University. Scientifically, we identified and deployed genes in potato that regulate virus pathogenicity in a strategy to control disease. We achieved a significantly better fundamental understanding of the targets in the ER stress machinery which could be used for gene editing approaches to manage virus disease in the field. This research advanced the field through the discovery of key factors in environmental stress regulation in potato for use in crop improvement, thereby spanning the spectrum from basic to translational research. The project deliverables l include a well-established system for comparative genetics of Arabidopsis, yeast, and potato for the discovery of novel host factors regulating virus-plant interactions.  This research approach could be broadly used by the scientific community. We functionally annotated genes in the agriculturally important crop, potato that are critical for crop improvement.   

We used several mechanisms to disseminate scientific information relating to this project.  First, we leveraged the existing communications infrastructure at the Texas A&M Agrilife Research. Dr Verchot, working with Mr. Gabe Saldana, Director of Communications at the Dallas Center, have together developed a stakeholder registry for research projects at the Center, including this work on viruses in potato.  To reach these stakeholders we posted monthly updated content to The Dallas Center website.  Twice per year we will feature articles related to this research to online news sites such as Agrilife Today or Morning Ag Clips which reach statewide, national, and international audiences with the accomplishments of Texas A&M Agrilife.  Next the Verchot team launched a UPROme gene expression database to reach the scientific community with content to enable broader studies of signal transduction pathways that may overlap the ER stress machinery.  We also reported genomic characterization to the SPUD DB hosted by the Buell lab.  When the laboratory moved to College Station,the Verchot team launched initiatives for student intern training hosting underserved communities.  Finally we included this work in the newest edition of Fields Virology, the most important textbook for virologists globally.
